title: How much extra would voicing my piano cost on top of tuning my piano (Yamaha upright piano)? - Quora

response.answer_text: It would be better to get a technician to answer this… but I don’t see any other answers. I looked around online; it was harder to find information than I thought it would be. The only source that put a dollar figure on it said roughly $125 for “steam” voicing, and $250 for traditional needle voicing. I admit I don’t know what steam voicing is. Those numbers sound low, though. A tuning costs somewhere around $150, and takes about 1.5 hours, plus maybe a half hour drive each way. So, assume you’re paying $60/hour for the tuner’s time. Doing a voicing right is at least a half-days work. That does suggest $250 or so for four hours of work, but I think that’s a lowball estimate. Needling each of the hammers to get them to the right hardness sounds like more than an afternoon’s work. So go from there.

there’s considerable variation in what technicians charge (correlates to cost of living in their area and fuel prices if they’re driving around to clients). more variation in what a particular piano would require, in the estimation of the person doing the work. the first time our upright was voiced, it was over $200, the second time, a briefer session from a different and more experienced technician, $100. you also need to establish how you want your piano to sound after the work, because your expectations might not be feasible depending on the piano and how much it’s been played.
